+mouthpiece200 Really? Is a consistent sense of morality really evident in 
all religious texts? When I say vast discrepancies I'm not exaggerating: 
some ancient religious texts justify murder all over the place while most 
of their followers deplore it, and others are simply full of 
illogicalities. So it would seem that even on the most fundamental issues, 
religions can't seem to agree. I would like to think humanity has 
progressed further in our understanding of morality than ideas that were 
written down hundreds of years ago. 
And I also think attempts to derive an absolute sense of morality are very 
evident throughout philosophy, without the need for a God to justify 
beliefs. Kant has a famous Categorical Imperative, which employs reason to 
attain an absolute moral law, while possibly a more well-known absolute can 
be seen in utilitarianism. These philosophies are generally much more 
nuanced and highly debated than many religious texts, and it is clear that 
debate refines and improves ideas.
The reason we agree on morality 'more often than not' is an evolutionary 
one. We have evolved as social beings and have come to a generally 
universal conclusion on what is right and what is wrong. A good example of 
this conclusion is the UN definition of human rights. This is, in a sense, 
absolute morality, that again has been derived without the need for a God.
low I.Q.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf Go get laid kid.  I'll bet your teacher asserted that 
5+5=10 over and over again until you were able to understand it.  
Get lost.

+mouthpiece200
Cute, a circular argument. Asserting the same thing over and over again, 
especially after an admission of defeat, does nothing to support your 
position.

+Campbell McLauchlan  If there was an absolute source of morality, then 
some god would have told us what it is.  It would be knowable by the text 
of some religion.  Most religions would agree that we have a sense of 
morality.  If there was an absolute morality, then this sense of morality 
would be loosely based on the absolute.  Humans agree on morality more 
often than not.  It is just that we put extra emphasis on the disagreements 
of morality.  But I never claimed there was any morality at all.

Even if an absolute sense of morality exists, how can anyone claim to 
appeal to it or even truly understand it? Surely the fact that we 
constantly debate moral issues and that there are such vast discrepancies 
in "religious morality" would at very least point to the fact that we don't 
have a very firm grasp of this absolute morality as a species. Then if this 
is the case, nobody really knows what is right and what is wrong and we are 
back with a subjective interpretation of morality. And it's as if the 
absolute source didn't exist at all.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf  Cute little bullying tactic, trying to pretend your 
opponent admits defeat.  That's on the same level as saying, "Have you told 
your mom that you're a homosexual?".  Shouting has no correlation with 
being right or wrong, but your insinuation that it implies wrong is 
evidence of your faulty logic, which implies that you yourself are wrong.  
Nor did I shout anyway.  That was Laughing! 

Semantics has everything to do with the issue.  If people are using words 
in a different way than I meant them, that is very notable issue.  So 
morality is a distinction between right and wrong?  Then atheists have no 
right to appeal to morality because right and wrong can only come from an 
absolute source.  Those things that you may think are right and wrong are 
not, they are culture values and biological predispositions.  If you 
disagree with me on that point, then our disagreement is once again - 
SEMANTIC.  You have now been EDUCATED.

+mouthpiece200 Well I think we can safely call that an admission of defeat, 
the cherry on top being the all caps shouting. Even if you're basing it 
just on semantics, you still fail, as by dictionary definition it is only a 
distinction between right and wrong. But you're not, and all you've done is 
shift the goalposts. Your original argument concerned an atheist's "right" 
to appeal to morality, which has absolutely nothing to do with the 
"semantics". This is a quote from you: "Morality cannot exist without an 
absolute source". That's quite the assertion there, and has nothing to do 
with semantics considering the very definition. You can go and cool down 
now.

Only semantics? It would seem to be the crux of this whole argument! If 
there's a disagreement with a definition it needs to be sorted out.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf You're too dull to see that debating the definition of 
morality is only a matter of semantics.  YOU FAIL!

Morality by definition is just the concept of distinguishing between right 
or wrong, everyone has their own sense of it. If you don't, you're probably 
a psychopath. As I've explained twice already, a sense of morality is 
achieved through societal consensus, internal values, evolutionary 
necessity and upbringing. When someone says "murder is wrong" and the 
majority agree, it's hardly surprising is it? It's not a difficult concept 
to grasp, only theist apologists tend to try and lend a ridiculous amount 
of license to what morality is really about, usually with the idea that an 
absolute must exist.

+Campbell McLauchlan Most precisely I'm agnostic, but close enough to 
atheism also.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf Reread the conversation and you'll see I never asserted 
that absolute morality exists.  I have personal preferences and values, not 
to be confused with a personal sense of morality.  Killing isn't wrong - 
there are plenty of acceptable justifications for it.  Although I would say 
most rapists DO have a problem with rape.  They sure wouldn't want their 
mom raped.  They just excuse themselves when it suits them.  This is not a 
question of value.  Personal and opinion based things are simply not 
morality.  They are personal and opinion based things.  Nor is a law or a 
societal norm morality.  As I said before, the idea of morality is always 
used as a universal concept.  When people say something is wrong, they mean 
for everybody.  Nobody ever says, "Murder is wrong for me, but you can do 
what you want".   Subjective morality is not morality in any sort of way 
the word is commonly used.

+mouthpiece200 Out of interest, what religion or otherwise do you subscribe 
to? You seem quick to defend yourself out of the realm of theism and yet 
somehow claim that there is moral absolutism out there for the taking. 
Please explain?
Get the fuck off your high horse.

So you don't have a personal sense of morality? And you aren't asserting 
that an absolute morality exists? I'm not even sure how that boat analogy 
sounded remotely well-thought out to you considering how nothing about the 
concept of morality necessitates being derived from a higher authority or 
absolute. I already answered some of what you said and I feel like I'm 
repeating myself now. Not everyone thinks murder is wrong and some justify 
it in certain situations, but considering how murder is a specific legal 
term "killing" would be more apt. And clearly rapists don't have a problem 
with rape. Something being personal and opinion based, which then becomes 
law and societal norm through consensus does not somehow lower its value.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf Show me where I ever asserted that absolute morality 
exists.  Subjective morality cannot exist, because its subjective nature 
nullifies its qualification as morality, just like a boat which cannot go 
underwater negates any chance of that craft being a submarine.  When 
something is subjective, we have other words that apply:  Opinion, belief, 
instinct, etc...  The term "morality" does not apply to matters of personal 
preference.  No one ever talks about good and bad as being relative terms, 
including this video.  Every usage of the words good and evil always 
implies a universal code.  You will never hear someone say, "Murder is 
against my personal morals."  But you will easily hear someone say, "Murder 
is wrong", which proves they have no intention of making a subjective 
statement.  Good and evil are used in an absolute context, pretty much one 
hundred percent of the time.  When the context is subjective, its simply 
called a difference of opinion or belief.  Ask someone if rape is wrong.  
They will NEVER tell you that it is just wrong for them.  Of course 
countries have different laws.  That's because people in different 
countries have different BELIEFS and OPINIONS.

Yes you did, but to prove my point, what do you consider an absolute 
authority?
As to the rest, all you're doing is repeating a Lane Craig-esque argument 
where you assert an absolute morality exists over and over again without 
actually explaining why things have to work that way. There is no reason to 
think subjective morality isn't morality - because of course it is. Even 
two people of the same denomination don't share an unshakeable objective 
moral standpoint, no two countries have the same laws, trying to appeal to 
some cosmic sense of justice doesn't work.
And yes, one act can be good and evil at the same time. It just depends on 
what your opinion is. There is no proven rationality behind your argument.

+Eadmund Isen-Healf Subjective morality is not morality.  It is opinion, 
feeling, culture, socialization, instinctual behavior, etc.., but it is not 
morality.  One single act can't be good and evil at the same time.  That's 
just a system of absurdity.  I never argued from authority - the 
rationality behind my arguments is authority enough.

That's just an argument from authority. You haven't shown why an absolute 
source needs to exist. Morality is subjective and is entirely personal 
depending on social norms, upbringing, and an innate sense of justice found 
in social animals.

Stephan, I am a harsh critic of the philosophy of nonviolence and hence of 
Gandhi ( http://newdemocracyworld.org/revolution/nonviolence.html ), and I 
found your talk about Gandhi's racism very interesting. One of your points, 
however, I find difficult to believe: your claim that the Indian 
independence movement owed its success mainly to the British having 
scruples against using violence against ordinary people, the "nonviolence 
of the British" as I think you phrased it.

The reason I doubt this viewpoint is because I've read (in Imperial 
Reckoning: The Untold Story of Britain's Guilag in Kenya, by Pulitzer Prize 
winning Caroline Elkins, a Harvard History professor) about the 
unbelievable torture and violence that the British used in the 1950s to try 
to prevent Kenya from gaining independence. To the extent that the British 
did not in fact use similar violence to prevent India from gaining 
independence, I suggest that some explanation be looked for other than the 
"nonviolence of the British." It is possible the British ruling elite did 
not fear Indian independence as much as Kenyan. Perhaps the British elite 
thought they would continue to make money in India even if it were formally 
independent (as is the case today: 
http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/india-clears-vodafone/938296.html 
.)Perhaps the British elite thought Kenyan independence would be more 
costly, or perhaps the substantial number of "white" British people settled 
in Kenya was a factor. Whatever the explanation, there is no historical 
evidence of a "nonviolent" inclination in the British ruling elite--quite 
the contrary.﻿

I realise that "hero worship" can demean a human, but, nonetheless, I have 
to take exception to your idea that excelling in anything else than 
philosophy and what relates to it is a waste of one's central intention. 
The ARTS, for example, are intrinsically valuable. That a great musical 
creator like Beethoven venerated his contemporary Cherubini in no way 
lessened the worth of Beethoven's own music. He absorbed a lot from a 
composer like Cherubini. Beethoven's own music would not have much of its 
value without the elements in it that he "imported" from Cherubini's great 
music. Anyone, of course, who is discouraged rather than inspired to 
greater things by admiration of another, is missing a lot in his life. 
However, those who aspire to greatness for what they themselves admire, to 
emulate it, are improved by their "hero worship" (crudely put).﻿

Molyneux observes that colonial countries had slower rates of growth than 
relatively non-colonial ones in the 19th and 20th centuries. He infers from 
this that colonialism was somehow less predatory than it is often made out 
to be. But how does this follow? Colonialism did not bring benefits to the 
colonial mother-countries as a whole (for the most part); it brought 
benefits to certain elite *sections* of the mother-countries.

Colonialism was an absolute disaster for India. To take just one example, 
India suffered about a dozen famines through the period of British rule, 
the last one occurring in Bengal in 1943. Since independence in 1947, there 
have been no famines, despite the fact that there have been at times food 
shortages even worse than those that resulted in famines under British 
rule. As Nobel-prize winning economist Amartya Sen has pointed out, this 
has been due in no small part to India's parliamentary democracy and free 
press (admittedly a legacy of British rule, although British rule had to be 
overthrown in order for this legacy to be realized). In a democracy with a 
free press, governments are afraid that they will be voted out of power if 
they allow a famine to occur. Therefore, whenever there is a food shortage, 
the government acts quickly to distribute the available food. This is why 
there has never, in recorded history, been a famine under a democracy. All 
famines have occurred under either colonial rule, absolute monarchy, a 
Communist state or military dictatorship. In these systems, information 
about food shortages is blocked due to ideology or the fear of subordinates 
have of being retaliated against for upsetting or embarrassing their 
superiors. 

Things haven't gone perfectly since the end of the Raj, but India's 
independence in 1947 was one of the best things that has ever happened to 
that country.﻿

I think it's necessary to expose these deeply flawed heroes such as Ghandi 
as well as the concept of hero worship, so I've no problem with SM doing 
so. That said, the Right (I include SM in this category) does take a little 
too much pleasure in attempting to knock the iconic heroes of the Left from 
their pedestals. Again, not that I have a problem with it as long as 
they're willing to look at the statuary in their own front lawns with equal 
scrutiny. They're not.

Of course the real agenda in the criticism here is not the larger issue of 
the perils of hero worship or even simply to provide necessary facts about 
an iconic figure that needs more scrutiny, but rather the attempt to employ 
the method of guilt by association as a political tool. That is to say that 
since Ghandi is a heroic figure mostly renowned by the Left (the Right 
never particularly liked him even before all this nasty stuff about his 
personal life came out) his flaws can thereby be associated with or 
attached to the Left. 

Claiming to be foremost a social scientist, and beyond Left or Right, 
Molyneux fails as an analyst, not in just what he says here but more 
importantly what he doesn't say, what he deliberately leaves out of his 
analysis (this was particularly true with his inept biased analysis of the 
Trayvon Martin case) which is the tactic of a propagandist, which I believe 
is what he is at core having suffered through too many of his lectures.

Molyneux rightly brings to light all the evils and controversies of Ghandi. 
What he doesn't do, is talk about why, despite this, Ghandi remains 
important culturally. Iconoclasm is welcome in this case but Ghandi was not 
just the creep that SM depicts him to be and exists at the mythical realm 
whether SM likes it or not. Unless you think that by exposing Ghandi's 
flaws his fame is thereby renounced. As an historian or social scientist 
worth a damn, SM needed to consider how Ghandi's flaws would, could or 
should affect his legacy. Apparently he never had the inclination to do so, 
which means he's operating at the level of a propagandist.

Ghandi exists at the level of myth just as most of the famous, revered 
dead, but since his life is not so far in the past and we do have access to 
facts about him that hitherto were unknown to most of us, it is important 
to get them out and talk about them. As our moral standards change, we 
revisit our old heroes to see if they still pass mustard, most don't. And, 
I'll repeat, I think it's important to expose Ghandi and any other revered 
figure for who they really were even if it doesn't jive with our mythology 
of them -- or especially so, but a myth, like a genie, is hard to put back 
into the bottle once let out.

Perhaps one of the most important slogans taken on by the Left, 
paraphrasing the bible, is "the truth shall set you free." Whitewashing 
someone's past in order to make them a hero was always a bad idea. So let 
Ghandi be Ghandi. Let educators tell the full truth about him. Richard 
Attenborough should have apologized for foisting his fiction of Ghandi on 
us. That said, no one is going to lose any sleep over the fact that Ghandi 
was a deeply flawed human being. Mostly, Ghandi is India's problem. They 
have to sort out what he means to them as time goes by. Many of us in the 
West were/are inspired by his civil disobedience as a political tactic and 
learning of his flaws doesn't change that part of his legacy. No one needs 
Ghandi on a pedestal. Look at the ancient gods of the Greeks and other 
cultures, these were highly flawed beings. They have their positive and 
negative features. One inspires, the other warns, they are both 
educational.﻿

i don't get this video. Certainly i haven't heard these things about Gandhi 
before because I never researched them. But how does him sleeping naked 
with his young relatives that logically affect his views on nonviolence? 
There are naked camping groups in the US where families sleep eat and camp 
out naked with their in-laws, legally, not "immorally." If Stefan became a 
sex offender, how would that invalidate everything he says in his videos? 
It does not. Similarly, sex scandals that the media focuses on in 
politicians should not somehow taint their views on policy/govt. How does 
that make any sense? I don't care if a politician cheated on his wife... I 
care about what he says.

The monastic practice of celibacy in India has a long history that is 
shared by monks in Chia. Practicing celibacy takes extreme devotion and may 
lead to some of the oddities that were expressed in this video due to 
unreleased sexual energy, which may be a similar characteristic of many sex 
scandals in priests. Without sexual harmony, these things are more likely 
to happen. That doesn't make his views on nonviolence wrong... i do not 
understand how such a logical fallacy can be promoted in this video. 

Similarly with racism against blacks, a shared cultural view on blacks has 
nothing to do with his views on nonviolence and does not make him a 
hypocrite. Racism is certainly unfortunate, but cultural views at a certain 
time in history are not sufficient to show that someone preaching 
nonviolence is a hypocrite. Our founding fathers were racist and some had 
kids with their slaves, does that mean they were all horrible people? I'm 
sure idiots who miss the point will decide to think I'm racist, but the 
fact remains that most of this video focuses on issues that aim to 
INDIRECTLY show that Gandhi's views on nonviolence are at odds with 
happenstances in the rest of his life. 

The evidence presented in this video before 30 minutes regarding his views 
on blacks being similar to animals, his adherence to a segregated unjust 
caste system, his sleeping with naked young relatives, does not have 
anything to do with his views on nonviolence against the British. What we 
can glean however is that he did not believe in fairness and nonviolence 
for all human beings, but for Indians of a higher caste in India. It's 
extremely difficult to understand what cultural beliefs such as 
discriminating beliefs of the caste system say about a person. Perhaps one 
argument could be that no one in the past in a society with a caste system 
or a history of slavery was as good as people today where better education 
has slowly eliminated slavery and racism....although that's extremely 
arguable since racism certainly exists to this day. 

Around the 30-35 minute mark, the topics discussed are much more relevant 
in discussing how Gandhi's image as a nonviolent, peaceful man is 
influenced not only by his intrinsic views, but the passivism of the 
British. Still that stuff remains murky and it would be nice to read more 
about this in detail than hearing the summary in a video. 

I don't know much about Gandhi's virtues so hopefully astute readers of 
this post can see that the point of this post is to critically examine the 
qualitative evidence presented in this video rather than to make a case 
that Gandhi was a great person. How do cultural beliefs carry over to 
beliefs in philosophy and science and ethics? The case that beliefs in a 
caste system or in racism against blacks, which exists to this day among 
many Indians, certainly may call into question how ethical a human with 
those beliefs can be and how well they can treat other human beings. But 
having those beliefs cannot invalidate Gandhi's view on nonviolence against 
only one specific group of people. I don't think we can make the case that 
Gandhi believed in equality and world peace, but that does not mean his 
views on nonviolence were exemplary (if they were - this was not discussed 
in the slightest in the video). 

Unfortunate also is how social movements develop from forces that are not 
necessarily well-intentioned. These institute's promoting Gandhi's views 
while failing to acknowledge his murderous past are indeed dishonest and 
ignorant. But at least they promote nonviolence, even if they did it in an 
ignorant way. Better than promoting something harmful off of a false 
pretense. ﻿

For those who are so opposed to all military activity that they will ignore 
simple facts,  ambulance drivers, medics, etc are non-combatants who do not 
carry weapons, even to defend themselves, and do not kill. Thus, the story 
of Gandhi happily shooting blacks for any reason is totally false.
Furthermore, Gandhi did "ambulance work" and encouraged other Indians 
living in South Africa to do it in order to show that they deserved equal 
rights as citizens (or in his case, foreign residents) in South Africa. By 
the way, Gandhi was sent to South Africa as a lawyer for a business 
consortium run by Indian Muslims, he considered all Indians in South Africa 
to be equal, regardless of supposed caste or religion, and he latter 
opposed the partition of India into Muslim and Hindu states for the way it 
was handled.

the British who created it by drawing its borders. Thus India as a nation

anybody else. I agree that hero worship is foolish. But I will not allow

Yes... I found the "sources" that Mr. Molyneux provided on his website

minded I'm disappointed to find the degree to which he presents highly 
controversial (and often unsubstantial) claims as "facts" with only weak,

channel some time ago and while I appreciated many videos I was put off by 
his arrogant personality, but it seemed to work for him so i overlooked it.

I am okay with presenting controversial material and even going after 
things for entertainment value to have a positive effect... see my video 
"Wake up Call to Black People" for example... but I don't see the value in 
retroactively assassinating the character of figures such as MLK or Ghandi 
as a positive way forward. These figures wouldn't even be on Stefan's or 
anyone's radar had they not been inspired and willing to pay with their 
lives for their cause. And the fact that they did in fact make a real 
impact, sometimes against all odds, is the only reason one might care to 
criticize them.

However imperfect these men were, the remarkable thing is what they did 
even though they were just as flawed as you and I. 

Stefan seems to believe that these types of videos serve a positive role in 
fighting against the danger of "Hero worship" as he calls it. in our 
context, it seems obvious to me that apathy is a much greater problem than 
hero worship. If anything, maybe a little dose of "hero worship" could be 
helpful to inspire people to take action and get off the bleachers of 
"infotainment".

Its unfortunate to me that he doesn't place more value on the reality that 
we can in fact make a real difference in this world, even as imperfect as 
we are. Both Ghandi, MLK, and countless others are great examples of that. 
Show there flaws, but in light of their achievements and you'll be inspired 
by it - even if you don't agree with them on every point. They tapped into 
something greater than long-winded arguments and frankly, we could use a 
lot more of that from people who dream of a more peaceful and just world.

the profits it gave, however the sole purpose of maintaining their colonial 
practices was simply because of the prestige benefit. Napoleon, who needed

Few corrections Stefan. Hinduism doesn't promote the caste system. Caste 
system was a creation by the Hindu elite. The religious texts of Hinduism 
mainly Vedas and Upanishads have no mention of the caste system. The 
problem is that Vedas were not written down and were spread orally (I 
know!) and the caste system evolved over the past 4500 years in the Indian 
society. It's a creation of the Hindus not the Hindu philosophy itself. It 
doesn't matter to me any way because I'm an Atheist and ironically Hinduism 
has a school of thought supports Atheism (yes!) and I couldn't care less 
again.
Anyway regarding Gandhi himself, The word "sleeping" in the East just means 
sleeping. It is a common practice for elders (parents, grandparents) to 
sleep along with their younger children, grandchildren and relatives since 
the dawn of civilization. This is the culture and has nothing to do with 
sex like it is perceived in the west. The letters that talk about all these 
sexual experiments are intertwined with the culture and it's extremely 
difficult to put the blame on considering the time and religious intensity 
that floated around back them. I'm not supporting Gandhi by any means but 
there are things to learn from him (non-violence) and ideas of his to 
refrain from (non-realistic & impractical principles). But the takeaway is 
that he is human not god, just like the hundreds of our historic heroes. 
And  as far as I'm concerned, he did something that takes a lot of courage 
and self sacrifice by embracing and promoting non-violence (quite similar 
to the non-aggression principle of Libertarians) and I'm fully aware of his 
not so shiny parts of his personality. I can't just discredit his 
achievements because of the same reason and I refuse to idiolize him or any 
other such historically portrayed heroes as gods.﻿

The word kaffir is used in South Africa to refer to a black person. Now 
widely considered an offensive ethnic slur, it was formerly a neutral term 
for South African blacks.

The word is derived from the Arabic term kafir (meaning 'disbeliver'), 
which originally had the meaning 'one without religion'.[1]

Portuguese explorers adopted the term to refer to black non-Muslim peoples 
when they became involved in the Arab slave trade along the Swahili Coast. 
Later, other European traders also adopted its use.[2]

Variations of the word were used in English, Dutch, and, later, in 
Afrikaans, from the 16th century to the early 20th century as a general 
term for several different peoples of Southern Africa. In Portuguese, and 
in Spanish, the equivalent cafre was used. The term acquired a distinctly 
derogatory meaning in the context of South African history, especially 
during the Apartheid era. In Afrikaans, the term is more commonly spelled 
kaffer.

In South Africa today, the term is regarded as highly racially offensive, 
in the same way as "nigger" in the United States and other English-speaking 
countries. It is seldom used as an isolated insult, but rather is used 
systematically by openly racist individuals when talking about black 
people, and as such was very common in the apartheid era. Use of the word 
has been actionable in South African courts since at least 1976 under the 
offense of crimen injuria: "the unlawful, intentional and serious violation 
of the dignity of another.

I do think the iconography of the ultra-passive pacifist is harmful.  And 
even if we admit that there are saints (meaning very rare genius), I don't 
know if Ghandi was a true saint (by that definition).
I have a feeling that Ghandi represents modernity's tendency to idealize a 
pacifist trivialization of "peace," and to imbue it with a kind of magical 
glory.
To me, real peace is a mature and sobered UNDERSTANDING and appreciation of 
human LIMITS.  That we be sobered by the fact of human limits, and that 
this sobriety would enrich our judgment as we face sometimes baffling 
social problems.
And one of the most important human limits is our sometimes substantial but 
always limited ability to tolerate frustration with grace.
Ghandi is an icon that represents an impossible standard, and I think it 
distorts a mature understanding of traditional religious values.

But where exactly does Mr Molyneux say a 'personality' comes from? I think 
in a large way it must come from a child's - and to perhaps a lesser extent 
- an adult's perceptions of other people as it matures, throughout life.

Personally, I'd find it impossible to argue that a personality is impacted; 
none, barely or even only partially by external factors over genetics. In 
fact, I'd find it as difficult to do that than to argue that physical 
attributes are more affected by external environmental factors than by 
genetics, generally of course.

From all we know of conditioning, this would be extremely difficult and I 
admire any student of debate or member of debate team who has attempted it, 
certainly as far back as the larger part of the last century. Not to 
mention the blatantly obvious question of; why advertising is so lucrative?

So, to get to my point!

Surely if it's conceded that a personality is formed from perceptions of 
others, I'm sure Mr Molyneux would concede that 'role models' are doubtless 
a *good* thing as well as of course a *bad* thing. But also, importantly an 
*unavoidable* thing.

Now, unfortunately, while Molyneux does a plumb job decrying hero worship 
as over sentimental, illogical and de empowering; he runs the risk of 
implying that any kind of adoration or even respect is seen as a little 
'backward'. There is of course a balance, like most things

...indeed, I'd say; like everything!

I see a great imbalance in the way people see themselves, the way they see 
others and the way they relate to one another, and I personally think it 
requires attention. But I think that the problem is that people are 'too' 
selfish not less selfish.

I get the impression, though I may be wrong, that Mr Molyneux has gotten so 
deep into Anarcho-Capitalism that he's lost sight of some of the pivotal 
aspects of any reasonably functioning society. Prehistoric societies going 
back for many millennia have been identified as 'human' on the grounds of 
attributes like having veneration for elders, those with wisdom. But many 
of these were close knit very small communities so the elder or wiser 
person was usually a relative. Not a two dimensional celebrity or even 
Gandhi of course.

I don't actually think Mr Molyneux is discounting role models, I merely 
think that in his fervour to rightly attack 'hero worship' he could have 
chosen one of at least forty or so individuals who quite openly flaunt the 
adulation of their fans for simply looking/acting/ good/sexy/greedy/hateful 
and basically satanic.

Gandhi never flaunted any of his attributes, he merely - as a human with 
similar or different flaws to Mr Molyneux's or my own - promoted love, 
tolerance, steadfastness, moral integrity and the adoration of one thing 
above all other things; God.

That he was imperfect comes as no surprise to my Mr Molyneux, but that you 
would try to use his whole existence here on earth as an attempt to shine a 
light on hero worship is laughable in the light of such persons as the; 
Kardashian's, GaGa's, Madona's and Obama's of this sick and increasingly 
Godless world.﻿

No shit, genius, no individual politician is going to single-handedly save 
anyone (save from what? Presumably the toxic ramifications of capitalism). 
That should be obvious to anyone (except apparently to your subscribers who 
are also expected to pay for this useless tidbit) but the more important 
unstated implication here is that people who work on behalf of the public 
are expected to save your life single-handedly, and failing to do so 
apparently makes them beneath your contempt. Classic, clueless Molyneux! 
The point of public service in a representational democracy, is just that, 
to represent via institutional democracy, to serve the needs of others in 
concert with others, by creating policy to address social concerns. So, 
those of you who share Molyneux's knee-jerk rage toward government are not 
doing so in an unbiased, unemotional, factual way, but rather, driven by 
your own unresolved issues with authority, i.e., daddy, I would claim.

My take on Molyneux (and all libertarians) is that daddy was a bastard (or 
at least an emotionally unavailable authoritarian) and so there is a 
profound ambivalence to daddy and by extension, authority. You can't trust 
government to save you (that's the way SM begins his thesis here) in the 
same way that you couldn't count on daddy to meet your needs. On the other 
hand, there is an awareness that proper authority is lacking in your life 
which is why libertarians prefer the authority so-called free trade (forget 
for a moment it doesn't and can't exist) and not the authority of 
government. Actually, I agree that government should not be an authority 
unto itself, that's totalitarianism, and not what we have theoretically. 
But this fantasy that without government "interfering" in your life, you'll 
do just fine surviving by your wits is sadly mistaken for most people. Of 
course no one survives on their wits alone, including the rich. In a 
libertarian society, unless you're born wealthy, you wouldn't have access 
to the education that Molyneux and his clueless subscribers have benefited 
from because the libertarian hypocrites would have pulled up this 
particular ladder behind them thereby forcing others to go without what 
they themselves have greatly benefited from. 

Some people, especially young Ron Paul supporters, forget or never knew, 
that without government protection, the wealthy and powerful made the lives 
of most people miserable: long work hours, little pay, health care only if 
you were lucky, no real access to higher education, etc. Ignorant, 
intellectually lazy little bastards of organized labor were apparently 
never told the reason you came from middle class homes is not due to the 
free market alone, but due to your grandfathers fighting for rights that 
have since been institutionalized, (mostly under FDR and LBJ. 
Unfortunately, many of these gains have been eroded in the last 40 years by 
reactionaries of the far right including libertarians). And, it's very easy 
to show correlations. How many societies with a large middle class are 
mixed economies (combining socialism and market concepts)? All of them. 
Which have the highest standards of living for the most people and also 
boast the happiest citizens? Deny there is a correlation between democratic 
socialism and social success? How many societies with deregulated free 
market capitalism have large middle classes? None. (Libertarians might 
argue that there is no free market to compare with. That's because free 
market is a myth. If it could exist, it would. So the best examples we have 
are societies with relatively little regulation on capitalism.) How did 
Pinochet's Chile do economically after Friedman's Chicago boys finished 
with it (read Iain MacSaorsa who wrote an illustrative article in Spunk 
online magazine)? Or look at Argentina in the 90s. (Most of the countries 
in South America have Leftist governments now precisely because of the 
failing of capitalism to work for all of society.) The common claims of 
socialism failing in the USSR, China, Cuba, etc, are bogus. What failed in 
these societies is not socialism, but totalitarianism. (I realize 
libertarians are not good with nuance and assume that socialism leads 
inevitably to totalitarianism but there is no example of it. None of these 
societies began with democratic socialism and reverted to totalitarianism, 
they all began as totalitarian regimes and failed at some significant level 
ultimately due to lacking democratic institutions.)

The most troubling part of this lecture was having to listen to SM talk 
with a straight face about the virtues of the British Empire in colonial 
India --and this from a libertarian/voluntarist. I hear this type of 
bullshit argument from the Right often: how the great West has delivered 
the savages from their dark age for their own good, albeit by conquering 
them and destroying their ignorant cultures. It's simply a reflection of 
their own ignorance and reveals a long way to go in the evolution of their 
own morality.

Yes, India had and still has a caste system. It's terrible. Were the 
British with their similar class system expected to enlighten the Indians 
by example? The violent, ignorant ways practiced in much of India at the 
time were appalling and the British certainly had some moral advantages, 
but not many, not really. Anyway, they were not there to set a moral 
example but to plunder. Same with the US. You can look at the US going into 
Iraq or Afghanistan similarly. It can be argued that the US is more 
enlightened in terms of gender relations and government structure but to 
use our so-called enlightenment as a rationale for causing the suffering 
and killing of thousands is an absurd moral position. The same goes with 
the British in India. Had either of us gone into the places and forced 
democracy on them for their own good, that would be wrong but at least it 
would be a worthwhile legacy. We didn't. We went in for our own immoral 
interests, to plunder. So, all of Sm's apologist attitude for the British 
in India is total horse shit and should be embarrassing for any 
"enlightened" thinker to propose. 

I mean, it can be argued that some Blacks are better off now than they 
would be had they remained in Africa. So what! Absurd argument. This is a 
common tactic of Molyneux's, he does this when talking about economic 
systems, too. Sure, many people's lives in the US are better now (if your 
criterion for better is more material wealth) with our market economy than 
they would be 100 years ago. Again, so what! Comparing two disadvantaged 
positions is a fallacious argument. There is another alternative SM never 
mentions, and that is, how better off people would be if their society had 
real democratic institutions in place. He doesn't mention it because he 
doesn't believe in democracy, only in dollarocracy.
